comments.author: mar...@matuska.org
comments.body:
libarchive/archive_read_support_filter_uu.c #523:
if (total == 0) {

total is always zero. It is set on #472 and never gets modified before "goto read_more" is hit. 

It was introduced in commit:
https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/commit/c00dfcb23599bd14b7ce1659f51cf855901f3577#diff-8370836615487f01a0d1bf5a03fd321d

The question is what the intention of the author was :)

comments.author: mar...@matuska.org
comments.body:
Jörg, could you please cross-check this solution:
https://github.com/mmatuska/libarchive/commit/5133d4086ccfda090cec3368f396eb2971b41222

comments.author: aarya@google.com
comments.issue_diff:
Summary: Timeout in libarchive_fuzzer.cc (was: Hang in libarchive_fuzzer.cc)
Status: WontFix (was: New)
comments.body:
This was a bad flaky testcase, see Reproducible: No in bug report. We always file reproducible bugs only, but sometimes a flaky testcase sneaks in. In that case, we file a bug, so then if it turns unreproducible, we auto-close the bug after 30 days (from last comment date). This gives chance for developer to try it out.

ClusterFuzz should auto-close this in a month, but i can do it now. Since you fixed it on trunk, ClusterFuzz didn't generate any new timeout crashes.

comments.body:
The issue is not reproducible, but very interesting:

==1==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: SEGV on unknown address 0x322a32323236 (pc 0x000000832aeb bp 0x7ffd249c1b00 sp 0x7ffd249c1aa0 T0)

>>> '322a32323236'.decode('hex')
'2*2226'

And see the input:
 SELECt($$$$$$$ >=01,1)BETWEEN( SELECT 42222222222222222222*2)AND (1,7618.e8 || 442E4*21)2e8 || 44444*4-427618*444044448

Doesn't arbitrary memory read look cool?

comments.body: Some fuzzers like libyaml one, this woff one, etc are hitting this unreproducible bug every now and then. Can you please take a look.

comments.author: kcc@google.com
comments.body:
I've been looking at https://clusterfuzz-external.appspot.com/v2/testcase-detail/5844991544918016

It has: 
#11 0x5810d1 in fuzzer::Fuzzer::StaticAlarmCallback() /src/libfuzzer/FuzzerLoop.cpp:252:6
...
113 #21 0x56dd4f in fuzzer::ReadDirToVectorOfUnits(char const*, std::__1::vector<std::__1::vector<unsigned char, std::__1::allocator<unsigned char> >, std::__1::allocator<std::__1::vector<unsigned char, std::__1::allocator<unsigned char> > > >*, long*, unsigned long, bool) /src/libfuzzer/FuzzerIO.cpp:80:14
114 #22 0x521c5b in fuzzer::FuzzerDriver(int*, char***, int (*)(unsigned char const*, unsigned 

i.e. it times out while reading the files and that crashes in all kinds of bad ways. 

Silly bug, should be fixed now. 
May I ask someone to update libFuzzer and see it this goes away?

comments.author: aizatsky@google.com
comments.body:
> May I ask someone to update libFuzzer and see it this goes away? 

FYI this happens automatically. We always build with libFuzzer tot.

comments.body:
I *think* this is fixed. 
If someone sees it again, please open a new bug.

comments.author: lemzw...@googlemail.com
comments.body:
I've sort of fixed that – to be more precise, the current testcase no longer triggers the slow behaviour with current git because of other sanitizing fixes.  However, I can't fix the general slowdown in similar fonts (this is, having an extremely large number of glyph indices pointing to empty glyphs, together with a very large number of numbered instances).

Maybe it makes sense to restrict the fuzzer tests to use only, say, two arbitrarily selected named instances.  Ditto for the faces within a TrueType Collection.

comments.author: jack....@gmail.com
comments.body:
Looking at fuzzer stats, the only botan fuzzer with slowest_unit_time_sec > 0 is ressol, which reads at 31 currently.

In practice this algorithm (modular square root, find y given x=y**2 modulo a prime) is normally exposed with arbitrary x but with primes from the built in ECC curves, rather than with arbitrary moduli. This is the (already fuzzed) OS2ECP API. So maybe ressol fuzzer should be disabled on OSS-Fuzz, or limited to using specific moduli instead of taking it as part of the fuzzer input and suffering these occasionally very slow executions.

comments.author: jack....@gmail.com
comments.body: I changed the ressol fuzzer to always compute for a fixed prime ('randomly' chosen by the deterministic RNG), instead of using fuzzer-chosen modulus. For last two days slowest_unit_time_sec == 0 for all botan fuzzers.

comments.author: alex....@gmail.com
comments.body: The timeout here is caused by a very high iteration count in the PBKDF2 key derivation for the passphrase. Not sure there's a sane way to avoid this?

comments.author: kcc@google.com
comments.body:
For this code, is it acceptable to run for many seconds given a 700 byte input?

Some of the options:

#1 Ignore. ClusterFuzz will not file any other timeout bugs until this one is fixed and if the timeouts happen frequently fuzzing will become very inefficient. 

#2 Introduce some kind of threshold for the iteration count, if that is allowed by the input spec

#3 Do #2, but only for fuzzing, 
see http://libfuzzer.info/#fuzzer-friendly-build-mode
(not too good, as we will not be fuzzing the production variant)

#4 make the iterations themselves faster so that we fit into the time budget

Here is our FAQ entry on the matter: 
https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/blob/master/docs/faq.md#how-timeouts-and-ooms-are-handled

comments.author: n.mav...@gmail.com
comments.body: I have replaced the included files with custom-made keys which have an iteration count of '1'. This should make the tests more efficient.

comments.author: alex....@gmail.com
comments.body: I suspect libFuzzer will figure out how to turn the iteration count into something gigantic again, it's very crafty.

comments.author: kcc@google.com
comments.body:
Werner, I've filed this manually because ClusterFuzz is failing to reproduce this OOM.
I also failed to reproduce it manually, but here is what I have: 

OOM happens here: 
1953789024 byte(s) (98%) in 1 allocation(s)
#0 0x4d4848 in malloc /src/llvm/projects/compiler-rt/lib/asan/asan_malloc_linux.cc:64
#1 0x6d0a45 in ft_alloc /src/freetype2/src/base/ftsystem.c:74:12
#2 0x645dd3 in ft_mem_qalloc /src/freetype2/src/base/ftutil.c:76:15
#3 0x60e21a in ft_mem_alloc /src/freetype2/src/base/ftutil.c:55:25
#4 0x64d476 in ft_mem_qrealloc /src/freetype2/src/base/ftutil.c:146:15
#5 0x60f38a in ft_mem_realloc /src/freetype2/src/base/ftutil.c:102:13
#6 0x6da0f1 in pcf_read_TOC /src/freetype2/src/pcf/pcfread.c:121:10
#7 0x6d6b1b in pcf_load_font /src/freetype2/src/pcf/pcfread.c:1200:13
#8 0x6d28d0 in PCF_Face_Init /src/freetype2/src/pcf/pcfdrivr.c:335:15
#9 0x650654 in open_face /src/freetype2/src/base/ftobjs.c:1189:15
#10 0x61b37d in ft_open_face_internal /src/freetype2/src/base/ftobjs.c:2259:19
#11 0x61da9f in FT_New_Memory_Face /src/freetype2/src/base/ftobjs.c:1279:12
#12 0x5118aa in LLVMFuzzerTestOneInput /src/freetype2/./src/tools/ftfuzzer/ftfuzzer.cc:204:10

1953789024 == 61055907 * 32
(32 == sizeof(*face->toc.tables))

In pcf_read_TOC we have 
  toc->count = 61055907

It bypasses the check for 
  if ( toc->count > stream->size >> 4 )
because the value of stream->size is something insanely large (even thought the input is tiny). 
Don't know why, but I suspect this is a gzip bomb.

Then we call 
  FT_NEW_ARRAY( face->toc.tables, toc->count )

since toc->count * 32 is slightly less than INT_MAX the allocation succeeds and we end up with a 2Gb array.
This kills half of our fuzzing jobs at startup. :( 

Attached is the closest I have to the reproducer. 
With this file we have 
  stream->size == 0x9b4e4f46
  toc->count == 0x4000003
and then FT_NEW_ARRAY( face->toc.tables, toc->count ) fails because 0x4000003 * 32 is too big. 

Is it possible to do something like this?

    if ( toc->count > kSomeLargeSaneValue )                                                     
      return FT_THROW( Invalid_File_Format );
60206caa4d104e1547187aae4aaf6bd4bbd12992
275 bytes
View

comments.author: lemzw...@googlemail.com
comments.body: Nothing that I can really do on the FreeType side.  However, I've now modified `ftfuzzer' to test only up to 10 (arbitrarily selected) bitmap strikes.  Given that this font reports 3469 strikes and 9995 glyphs, this should certainly help :-)

comments.author: kcc@google.com
comments.body:
Just to confirm:
arbitrary, but still deterministic (same behavior for same input), right? 
Sounds good.

comments.author: lemzw...@googlemail.com
comments.body: Of course deterministic: Using a constant seed for `rand'.

comments.author: kcc@google.com
comments.body:
There is a theoretical problem with using srand(12345) on every iteration.
Suppose ClusterFuzz finds a bug and you are trying to reproduce it on your machine. If the glibc implementation of rand/srand differs between your and CF's
machines, you may not be able to reproduce the bug. 
I haven't seen this in practice though.

comments.author: kcc@google.com
comments.body:
There is a theoretical problem with using srand(12345) on every iteration.
Suppose ClusterFuzz finds a bug and you are trying to reproduce it on your machine. If the glibc implementation of rand/srand differs between your and CF's
machines, you may not be able to reproduce the bug. 
I haven't seen this in practice though.

comments.author: lemzw...@googlemail.com
comments.body: Point taken.  I now use the `xorshift' algorithm :-)

comments.author: lemzw...@googlemail.com
comments.body:
I've just applied a patch that should improve the issue a bit.

However, I can't improve the general behaviour, unfortunately.  The font in question has identical, problematic bytecode for a large number of glyphs, and the loop limit gets exceeded for every glyph that has bytecode.

It's the philosophy of FreeType to abort hinting on a per-glyph basis, not globally.  Normally, you simply can't expect that a font fails for every glyph in such a slowing down way.

It probably makes sense to adjust the fuzzer test itself.  Some ideas:

  (1) Switch off hinting if the number of processed glyphs is to slow.
  (2) Don't test all glyphs in a font, but only a selected number, say, 100.

What do you think?

comments.author: kcc@google.com
comments.body:
Confirmed, much better now for this input. 

No silver bullet here. 
On the one hand, the more limits you put into the fuzz target (that are not
present in the production code) the more disconnect we will have between fuzzing and real life.
OTOH, w/o any limits fuzzing will get so slow that it will become useless. 
So, if you can somehow limit the number of similar repetitive actions while fuzzing it probably makes sense.

comments.author: ClusterFuzz-External
comments.body:
ClusterFuzz testcase 4781190976372736 is verified as fixed, so closing issue.

If this is incorrect, please add ClusterFuzz-Wrong label and re-open the issue.

comments.author: lemzw...@googlemail.com
comments.body:
Well, then it's probably best that I do nothing :-)

Of course, it is good to find extremely slow samples so that I can adjust the guarding parameters.  Such samples should be acknowledged, then moved away.

On the other hand, there already exists TT_CONFIG_OPTION_MAX_RUNNABLE_OPCODES – do you still use it?

comments.author: kcc@google.com
comments.body:
>> TT_CONFIG_OPTION_MAX_RUNNABLE_OPCODES – do you still use it?
It got lost, apparently. 
where in this file should we add it?
https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/blob/master/projects/freetype2/build.sh

comments.author: lemzw...@googlemail.com
comments.body:
Replace

  ./configure

with

  ./configure CPPFLAGS="-DTT_CONFIG_OPTION_MAX_RUNNABLE_OPCODES=10000"

This is untested.  Note that I don't know whether 10000 is a good value; maybe it's too small.

comments.author: kcc@google.com
comments.body:
Will keep this option in mind. 
In the meantime I've reduce the maximal input size for freetype from 
300K to 30K: 
https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/commit/9104a53d2b8e28fa154325e9d948451e2ae0a43f

Since we now have smaller seeds in the corpus it should not reduce coverage too much (in the long term) but will hopefully avoid most of the timeouts.

comments.body:

comments.body: Looks like a duplicate of #462 “event_has_hard_overrides is run once per \r but should be once per event”, which was recently autoclosed. I guess the test case was taking just about 25 seconds and randomly happened to be slightly faster once.

comments.author: kcc@google.com
comments.body:
Yes, this is quite likely. I've tried this input on my local box and it takes 
22 seconds (with all the instrumentation we add). 
ClusterFuzz runs on VMs, so it's very likely that the time varies between 
< 25 seconds and > 25 seconds.

comments.author: kcc@google.com
comments.body: FTR: we are discussing similar issues in https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/issues/314

comments.author: kcc@google.com
comments.body:
BTW, the same input causes a leak report. 
==48==ERROR: LeakSanitizer: detected memory leaks

Direct leak of 256 byte(s) in 1 object(s) allocated from:
    #0 0x4d8b68 in malloc /src/llvm/projects/compiler-rt/lib/asan/asan_malloc_linux.cc:66
    #1 0x732759 in FcPatternObjectInsertElt (/out/libass_fuzzer+0x732759)


(the report looks not very informative, probably due to https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/issues/263)

comments.author: ddkil...@apple.com
comments.body:
Here's the minimal command to reproduce using xmllint within a libxml2 repo compiled with ASan enabled:

$ ASAN_OPTIONS=redzone=128 ./xmllint --memory --valid ./clusterfuzz-testcase-4626005117370368.dms.xml

(Actually, the --memory switch is not required, although that's closer to what libxml2_xml_read_memory_fuzzer uses.)

comments.author: ddkil...@apple.com
comments.body:
Can we get Daniel Veillard CC-ed on this bug?  I think it's going to help to have a XML parsing expert.

Here's a less-mangled version of the PoC that still reproduces:

<!DOCTYPE b [ <!ATTLIST b xmlns ID "i"> ]>
<b>

Note that changing the “"i"” to “#REQUIRED” or “#IMPLIED” makes the bug stop reproducing.

comments.author: ddkil...@apple.com
comments.body:
> Can we get Daniel Veillard CC-ed on this bug?  I think it's going to help to have a XML parsing expert.

Actually, I'll just file an upstream bug and discuss it with him there.

comments.body:
+veillard@

>> Actually, I'll just file an upstream bug and discuss it with him there.
Sure. 
Daniel, do you want to be CC-ed to other bugs like this? 
If yes, I will add you to https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/blob/master/projects/libxml2/project.yaml

ddkil...@apple.com
comments.body:
Please note that Apple will be shipping the fix that I posted here very soon:
<https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=780228>

This may not cover a possible info-leak mentioned in Comment #11, but it fixes the out-of-bounds write.

We will be requesting a CVE-ID for this issue as well.

comments.body: Shailesh - did you already request a CVE for this issue? (CVE-2017-0663)

comments.body:
This bug is approaching its deadline for being fixed, and will be automatically derestricted within 7 days. If a fix is planned within 2 weeks after the deadline has passed, a grace extension can be granted.

comments.author: shaileshs@google.com
comments.body:
#15 -> Android used CVE-2017-0663 for this issue

Not sure what the disclosure deadline is but the Android fix will be released as part of the June Android Security Bulletin (June 5, 2017 at 11:00 AM). Would it be possible to get an extension on the disclosure of this issue until that date?

comments.author: ochang@google.com
comments.body:
Unfortunately, the disclosure deadline we apply is for for the upstream library/maintainers, and not for any consumers for that project.

This report will be automatically de-restricted in 7 days (90 days since the report). If there is an upstream fix planned within that time, we can apply a grace extension of 14 days.

comments.author: ochang@google.com
comments.body:
> If there is an upstream fix planned within that time, we can apply a grace extension of 14 days.

Clarifying my comment here: 

If there is an upstream fix planned within 14 days after the 90 day deadline, we can apply a grace extension of 14 days.

comments.author: dominicc@chromium.org
comments.body: Chrome does not configure libxml2 with LIBXML_VALID_ENABLED so I believe we are unaffected by this bug; all of the callers of xmlValidateOneNamespace are ifdefed behind that.

comments.author: ddkil...@apple.com
comments.body:
> If there is an upstream fix planned within 14 days after the 90 day deadline, we can apply a grace extension of 14 days.

There is an upstream fix planned:
<https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=780228>

It's a matter of having an upstream maintainer (Daniel Veillard) look at it.

comments.author: ddkil...@apple.com
shaileshs@google.com
comments.body: The Android fix is exactly the same as the one posted in comment #25.

comments.author: alex....@gmail.com
comments.body:
Heh. So our fuzzer relies on sending the test data into a unix domain socket (streaming) so that we have a socket to read it from (gnutls works on sockets); it looks like we hit some buffer size around 1MB.

Is there a better solution than just having it return immediately on input with size > 1024 * 1024?

comments.author: n.mav...@gmail.com
comments.body: One alternative could be to set callbacks with gnutls_transport_set_pull_function() and gnutls_transport_set_pull_timeout_function() to retrieve data directly from the buffer instead of using sockets. That would add some complexity in the fuzzer though.

comments.author: alex....@gmail.com
comments.body: I think ultimately that'd be the right direction to go long term, but it seems like that should be functionality in gnutls itself, not in the fuzzers -- similar to how OpenSSL has memory bios.

comments.author: n.mav...@gmail.com
comments.body: That seems like a good idea. It may worth keeping an issue about it.

Stack overflow (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stack_overflow_(disambiguation)) and Stack buffer overflow(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stack_buffer_overflow)
often get confused. Stack-overflow should be called Stack-exhaustion from day 1 but someone coined it and folks just followed it :(

comments.author: robryk@google.com
comments.body:
What happens is that we quantize a coefficient away from zero, overflow the variable, and thus the end result is not divisible by the quantization constant.

We probably want to reject such large input coefficients in the first place.

comments.author: robryk@google.com
comments.body:
Separately: this seems to be an invalid JPEG. We should probably reject this one during parsing:

$ djpeg -v -v -v < ~/Downloads/clusterfuzz-testcase-5737651426557952  >/dev/null
...
Start Of Scan: 3 components
    Component 3: dc=1 ac=1
    Component 2: dc=2 ac=1
Invalid component ID 1 in SOS

comments.author: robryk@google.com
comments.body:
Re #2: the validity of this JPEG is a red herring (it's technically invalid, but libjpeg rejects it due to a non-standards-compliant workaround it uses).

https://github.com/google/guetzli/commit/d21005a180f1973818c517863c10af8d5be8747d rejects large coefficients and should fix this problem.

comments.author: even....@gmail.com
comments.body: Looking

comments.author: even....@gmail.com
comments.body:
Fixed per https://trac.osgeo.org/gdal/changeset/38253

libtiff upstream fix:

2017-05-13 Even Rouault <even.rouault at spatialys.com>

        * libtiff/tif_read.c: update tif_rawcc in CHUNKY_STRIP_READ_SUPPORT
        mode with tif_rawdataloaded when calling TIFFStartStrip() or
        TIFFFillStripPartial(). This avoids reading beyond tif_rawdata
        when bytecount > tif_rawdatasize.
        Fixes https://bugs.chromium.org/p/oss-fuzz/issues/detail?id=1545.
        Credit to OSS-Fuzz


/cvs/maptools/cvsroot/libtiff/ChangeLog,v  <--  ChangeLog
new revision: 1.1228; previous revision: 1.1227
/cvs/maptools/cvsroot/libtiff/libtiff/tif_read.c,v  <--  libtiff/tif_read.c
new revision: 1.59; previous revision: 1.58

comments.author: kcc@google.com
comments.body:
Even,
it's great that you are fixing bugs in the dependency (libtiff). 
Would you be interested in adding libtiff itself to oss-fuzz? 
Or at least in asking the other libtiff maintainers to do so? 
Fuzzing libtiff directly (not via gdal) is likely to be much more efficient.

comments.author: welln...@aevum.de
comments.body: Probably the same as https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=719350

comments.author: welln...@aevum.de
comments.body: This is most likely caused by libxml2_xml_read_memory_fuzzer.cc setting the XML_PARSE_HUGE option. (Parser options are set based on a hash of the input.) This option disables some recursion limits, so the result is completely expected. It's probably the best idea to make sure that libxml2_xml_read_memory_fuzzer.cc doesn't enable the HUGE option.

comments.author: he...@nerv.fi
comments.body: Where was this automatically filed in upstream or does that mean this issue report? If it was automatically reported to upstream could you show the link in here or is email only used?

comments.author: kcc@google.com
comments.body:
henri@, these bugs are automatically filed only here, we do not have any mechanism to report them to LLVM's bugzilla. 
Also note that we generally do not promise to reply on these bug reports. If you need support from the oss-fuzz team, please file an issue at https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/issues. 
Or mail to llvm-dev (CC: kcc) for LLVM-specific questions.

comments.author: jak...@gmail.com
comments.body:
AFAIK, this is caused by the limited size of buffers for send(). I think we should not try to push all data (in last example 214 KB) to send and hope it will get through, but rather define some kind of encoding of the fuzzer data, which would allow us to split the big chunk of data to "packets"/"messages", that could be sent one at a time when needed, similarly as we do in opensc:

https://github.com/OpenSC/OpenSC/blob/master/src/tests/fuzzing/fuzz_pkcs15_reader.c#L46

This would be something to work on later.
